Hydrogenolysis of guaiacol and lignin to phenols over Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst Xiaohong Ren Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Data curation Zeming Rong Funding acquisition ⁎ Xiaoqiang Yu Resources Conceptualization State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116012, PR China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals School of Chemical Engineering Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116012 PR China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116012, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Selective hydrogenolysis of CAr-O bonds in lignin to produce aromatic compounds typically necessitates severe conditions. We developed a Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst that facilitates direct cleavage of guaiacol's aryl ether bonds at reduced temperatures (200 °C) and pressure (0.1 MPa H2), achieving a conversion of 89.5 % with the selectivity of phenol at 81.7 %, while retaining its activity after five cycles. The Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 exhibits a higher yield of phenol (49.1 mmolphenol·gNi −1·h −1), currently achieving the highest phenol yield among Ni-based catalysts. The addition of Nb2O5 enhances the dispersion of Ni and augments the effective surface area. In addition, the strong interaction of Nb with the HZSM-5 changed the electronic state of Nb and enhanced the resistance of the catalyst to high temperature and mechanical stress. Employing this catalyst for lignin depolymerization in an aqueous medium led to a 17.0 wt% yield of alkyl phenolic compounds. This approach represents an advancement in biomass resource conversion, circumventing the dependency on high-pressure and precious-metal catalysts, and signaling a new trajectory for sustainable biomass utilization in scientific research. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Water Hydrogenolysis Ni/Nb2O5-HZSM-5 catalyst Lignin Guaiacol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The increasingly serious environmental problems associated with over-exploitation force human society to seek alternative low-carbon energy sources[1,2]. Upgrading of lignocellulosic biomass provides a unique opportunity to utilize a renewable resource to create these fuels and chemicals from waste materials and plants that do not compete with food production[3-6]. Lignin is the only large-volume sustainable feedstock for aromatic chemicals in nature, accounting for 10–35 % of woody biomass and it is an ideal sustainable resource to replace the traditional petroleum-based process for the production of aromatic chemicals[7-11]. However, due to the high dissociation energy of the CO bond (218–314 kJ·mol−1), the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring is preferentially carried out before CO bond cleavage in most cases[12]. Thus, the production of valuable aromatic compounds from lignin and lignin-derived compounds by selective hydrodeoxygenation reactions is a major challenge. Phenol is one of the most valuable bulk chemicals, primarily synthesized through the cumene process, which consumes a significant amount of petroleum-derived benzene[13,14]. Therefore, replacing petroleum with renewable biomass as a raw material for phenol production holds tremendous significance. Noble metal catalysts have been regularly used in the hydrogenolysis of guaiacol due to their high activity and low barrier for H2 activation. For example, Liu et al. investigated the Ag/TiO2 catalyst in the hydrogenolysis of guaiacol and proposed that oxygen vacancies on the surface of TiO2 might serve as deoxygenation sites to produce phenol while Ag was responsible for H2 dissociation. At 300 °C and 3 MPa H2, the yield of all phenolic products is around 64 % in 3 h [15]. The guaiacol hydrogenolysis reaction on an Au/TiO2 catalyst at 4 MPa H2 pressure demonstrated 70 % phenol selectivity at 92 % conversion[16]. The MgO-supported Pt catalyst could avoid deactivation by coke deposition and the selectivity to phenol could reach 50 % on the catalyst at 92 % guaiacol conversion, but catechol and cyclopentanone were formed as byproducts[17-19]. However, a problem in the utilization of noble metal catalysts is the high price. Supported Fe-based catalysts were applied in a guaiacol hydrogenolysis reaction. Tomishige et al. adopted Fe/CeO2 catalysts in guaiacol hydrogenolysis and obtained a high phenol yield of 56 % at 400 °C[13]. In another study, Pt-Fe/CeO2 exhibited a high phenol selectivity of around 60 % under comparable reaction conditions[20]. Recently, supported Ni-based catalysts are recognized as efficient and low-cost ones in the hydrogenolysis of guaiacol and a range of materials have been reported as catalyst supports, including γ-Al2O3, mesoporous SiO2, ZrO2, zeolites, TiO2, and activated carbons[21-25]. Furthermore, the substantial interactions between the metal and support can manipulate the piled configuration and quantity of active species, leading to the creation of numerous proactive hubs demonstrating high activity. Unfortunately, prevailing research primarily centers on employing pure oxides as supports, and the hydrogenolysis process is frequently executed under somewhat stringent conditions such as temperatures exceeding 200 °C and H2 pressures surpassing 5 MPa. These severe conditions result in high H2 consumption and complete saturation of the aromatic ring. Consequently, it becomes crucial to engineer Ni-based catalysts that exhibit elevated catalytic activities for the hydrogenolysis of guaiacol, which can be attained under comparatively milder temperatures and H2 pressures. Nb2O5 with both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites can significantly facilitate the CO bond breakage of lignin derivatives. Nb2O5 is a typical solid acid catalyst with unique water resistance and its acidity has been investigated in many aqueous media reactions, demonstrating its stable acid catalytic properties[26-29]. Therefore, we report high selectivity and stability Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 with a high H2-utilization efficiency for the hydrogenolysis of guaiacol to phenol at mild conditions. The guaiacol conversion of Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 was 74.4 % and the phenol selectivity was 85.7 %, even after recycling five times, it still had good activity and selectivity. After doping with Nb2O5, the Ni/HZSM-5 exhibited several improvements: the pore size was enlarged, which enhanced the thermal stability and mass transfer efficiency, while the size of Ni nanoparticles was reduced, which enhanced the contact efficiency with the reactants. These small particles were easily stabilized by the HZSM-5 due to their high surface energy, reducing aggregation and enhancing the stability of the catalyst. In addition, the strong interaction of Nb with the HZSM-5 changed the electronic state of Nb and enhanced the resistance of the catalyst to high temperature and mechanical stress. Besides, the effects of different process parameters, including screening of solvents, reaction temperature, reaction pressure, catalyst amounts, and causes of catalyst deactivation are investigated in the designed conditions. In addition, the catalytic depolymerization of lignin was carried out by Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 under the reaction system of pure water at 240 °C and 0.1 MPa H2 pressure. The yield of alkyl phenolic compounds was obtained as 17.0 wt%. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was purchased from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory and used as a Ni precursor. CO(NH4)2 was purchased by Guangdong Guanghua Sci-Tech Co., Ltd. Support materials (HZSM-5, Nb2O5) were purchased from Wuxi Zehui Chemical Co., LTD. Methanol, ethanol, and isopropanol were purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. Guaiacol, cyclohexanone, cyclohexanol, and phenol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Hydrogen was supplied by Air Liquide company. Deionized water was obtained from a Millipore system. All chemicals were analytical grade and used as received without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst The supported Ni catalysts were prepared according to the deposition−precipitation (DP) method, and the experimental procedure was as follows. Firstly, Nb2O5 and HZSM-5 are mixed in a mass ratio of 1:3 to serve as the catalyst support. This ratio ensures uniform distribution and sufficient contact between the components of the support. The supports (2 g) were added into an aqueous solution containing Ni salt (7.9 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O diluted with 40 mL of deionized water). Then, the suspension was heated to 95 °C with constant stirring for 1 h, and a little silica sol (600 μL) was added into the suspension for another 1 h. The precipitant solution (4.9 g of CO(NH2)2 diluted with 40 mL of deionized water) was dripped into the above mixture. After a given time of deposition−precipitation (20 h), the suspension was cooled to 25 °C and then filtered. The sample was washed with distilled water and ethanol to remove possible adsorbed ions and dried at 60 °C for 24 h. The dried precursor was heated to 500 °C at a heating rate of 7.5 °C·min−1 under N2 and reduced for 4 h in 20 mL·min−1 H2. The catalyst was cooled to room temperature under N2 and gradually exposed to air for 10 min for further usage. 2.3 Characterization of catalyst The N2 adsorption−desorption isotherms were characterized using a 3H-2000PS1 sorption system (Beishide Instrument-ST Co., Ltd.). The catalysts were degassed for 2 h at 200 °C before the measurement. The related data were calculated by the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method and the Barrett−Joyner−Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a SmartLab 9KW with CuKα radiation, operated at 45 kV and 20 mA. The scanning range (2θ) was recorded from 10 to 100° at a scanning rate of 10°·min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) measurements were obtained by using an ESCALAB with Al Kα (1486.6 eV) as the photon source. The binding energy was calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. Different catalysts were measured by a NanoSEM 450 to analyze the surface morphology. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images and energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) mapping images were obtained with a FEI Tecnai G2 operated at 200 kV. Before the sample test, the Ni-based catalyst was first dispersed in 10 mL of ethanol and sonicated for 30 min, and a few drops of supernatant liquids were poured on the double−folding grids. The content of metal elements in the catalyst was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). 200 mg of the sample catalyst was dissolved in aqua regia and then diluted to 100 mL for testing. 2.4 Assessment of catalyst activity The HDO of guaiacol in the aqueous phase was carried out in a closed 75 mL stainless-steel batch reactor. In general, 2 mmol guaiacol, 15 mL of water, and a certain mass of catalyst were put into the reactor. The reactor was sealed and then purged with N2 10 times for each to remove the residual air. The reactor was then heated to a certain temperature, and the specified reaction time was maintained, with the speed adjusted to 800 rad·min−1. The reaction products were identified by an Agilent 5975C GC–MS and quantified by a GC7890F gas chromatograph with a flame ionization detector (FID). The GC7890F-type gas chromatography column was a DP-FFAP (30 m × 320 μm × 0.50 μm). The column temperature was raised as follows: the initial temperature was 50 °C and kept for 5 min and then, the temperature was raised to 220 °C at 20 °C·min−1 and kept for 40 min. All catalyst activity tests were repeated at least twice. After the reaction, accurate quantification was carried out using sec‑amyl alcohol as an internal standard. The carbon balance for all reported experiments in the liquid phase was better than 95 ± 3 % in this work. The carbon selectivity (C%), product selectivity, and guaiacol conversion were calculated using eqs1−3, respectively. (1) C ( % ) = moles of product × C n u m b e r moles of guaiacol reacted × C n u m b e r i n g u a i a c o l × 100 (2) s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = C m o l e s × product total C m o l e s of products × 100 (3) c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = m o l e s o f g u a i a c o l r e a c t e d total moles of guaiacol × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the Ni-based catalysts The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter of three catalysts (Ni/Nb2O5, Ni/HZSM-5, and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5) were determined using N2 physical adsorption-desorption techniques. The results of these measurements are crucial for a thorough understanding of the structural characteristics of the catalysts, which in turn can help predict their catalytic activity and stability. Analysis of the isotherm adsorption-desorption curves reveals that both Ni/Nb2O5 and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 exhibit Type IV isotherms with H4 hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of a distinct mesoporous structure in these materials (Fig. 1a , c). The mesoporous structure contributes to the catalyst providing more accessible surface area and better mass transfer performance[30,31]. On the other hand, the adsorption isotherm of Ni/HZSM-5 is of type I, indicating that the catalyst mainly has a microporous structure (Fig. 1b). Microporous structures are typical for zeolite catalysts, offering highly selective catalytic activity. However, their limitations in physical adsorption can often impact their efficiency in certain reactions[32,33]. After doping with Nb2O5, the pore volume and pore diameter of the Ni/HZSM-5 catalyst increased significantly, indicating that the addition of Nb2O5 has a notable effect on the microstructure of the catalyst. Specifically, the pore volume increased from 0.19 mL·g −1 to 0.62 mL·g −1, and the pore diameter expanded from 3.8 nm to 12.4 nm (Table 1 ). Firstly, the increase in pore size helps reduce diffusion limitations within the catalyst, enabling larger reactant molecules to more easily access the active sites inside the catalyst[34]. Additionally, the increased pore volume also contributes to the stability of the catalyst during continuous use, as larger pore structures are beneficial in reducing clogging issues caused by polymers or other blockages[35,36]. These changes do not have a significant impact on the catalyst's specific surface area. This may be because, while the number of larger pores has increased, the overall pore structure's contribution to surface area may be offset by a higher density of micropores or smaller pore structures [37,38]. The significant increase in pore size and volume indicates a marked change in the physical properties of the material, likely due to the strong interaction between Nb2O5 and HZSM-5. To further investigate the mechanism of this interaction, FTIR analysis was performed on the Ni/HZSM-5, Ni/Nb2O5 and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5, as shown in Fig. 2 . FTIR analysis provides a deeper understanding of the chemical bond formation and interactions within the Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 system, thereby elucidating the impact of Nb2O5 on the structure and performance of the HZSM-5. The FTIR spectrum reveals several key absorption bands that correspond to different functional groups and bonds within the catalyst. The peak at 3408 cm⁻¹ is attributed to the OH stretching vibration, indicating the presence of surface hydroxyl groups. The peak at 2352 cm⁻¹ corresponds to the C = O stretching vibration in CO₂, which is attributed to errors introduced during the testing process. The peaks at 1621 cm⁻¹ and 1629 cm⁻¹ are associated with the bending vibration of water molecules' OH groups, suggesting the possible presence of adsorbed water on the catalyst surface. Further, the bands at 1208 cm⁻¹, 1094 cm⁻¹ and 840 cm−1 are ascribed to the Si-O-Si or Al-O stretching vibrations, which confirm the framework structure of HZSM-5 (Figure2a, 2c). The peak at 942 cm⁻¹ corresponds to the stretching vibrations of Nb-O-Si or Nb-O-Al bonds, highlighting the interaction between Nb2O5 and the HZSM-5 (Fig. 2c). The absorption bands at 1213 cm⁻¹, 823cm⁻¹ and 807 cm⁻¹ are attributed to the deformation vibrations of Nb-O or Nb-O-Nb bonds, indicating the presence of Nb2O5 (Fig. 2b, 2c). Finally, the peaks at 671 cm⁻¹ and 540 cm⁻¹ are attributed to the Ni-O stretching vibration, signifying the presence of nickel oxides. These detailed FTIR analyses provide valuable insights into the structural and chemical changes induced by Nb2O5 in the HZSM-5, demonstrating the interaction between Nb2O5 and HZSM-5. To further verify the interaction between Nb2O5 and HZSM-5, XPS was employed to conduct a detailed surface chemical analysis of the Ni/Nb2O5, Ni/HZSM-5, and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalysts. This technique allows for the accurate determination of the chemical states and electronic environments of Ni, Nb, Si, and Al elements on the surfaces of the catalysts. Correction of the XPS peaks for all elements using C1s (284.8 eV) as an internal standard is a critical step in ensuring the accuracy of the analyzed data. This correction allows precise comparison of chemical state changes between samples. In the Ni/Nb2O5, Ni/HZSM-5, and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalysts, Ni exhibited the same binding energy trend (Fig. 3 a-c). The primary binding energy peaks for Ni are at 855.7 eV and 873.8 eV, corresponding to the NiO 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbitals, a result of spin-orbit splitting. The split peak of NiO's 2p3/2 is at 857.8 eV, while the signal at 852.6 eV is attributed to Ni0. Additionally, satellite peaks at 861.9 eV and 879.6 eV further confirm the presence of Ni in multiple oxidation states in these catalysts. Due to the high activity of Ni which is oxidized during the XPS test, and the surface properties of the catalyst, the amount of Ni0 on the surface may be low, which results in a relatively small Ni0 peak[39,40]. In the Ni/Nb2O5 catalyst, the peaks at 207.2 eV and 210.1 eV are attributed to Nb5+ 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively. The prominent photoelectron peaks of Nb indicate that Nb2O5 exists as an independent phase in this system, with a relatively high concentration (Fig. 3d). After doping a small amount of Nb2O5 into Ni/HZSM-5, the photoelectron peaks of Nb in the XPS spectrum significantly decrease or even disappear (Fig. 3g). This suggests that the state of Nb2O5 in this system has changed. A strong interaction has likely formed between Nb2O5 and HZSM-5, causing Nb2O5 to no longer exist as an independent phase but rather to interact or combine with the HZSM-5. This interaction may involve the formation of chemical bonds, such as Nb-O-Si or Nb-O-Al bonds, leading to the weakening or disappearance of the characteristic photoelectron peaks of Nb in the XPS spectrum. This phenomenon is consistent with the results from FTIR characterization, further confirming the significant chemical interaction between Nb2O5 and HZSM-5. This strong interaction enhances the structural stability of the catalyst, making it more resistant to high temperatures and mechanical stress[41,42]. After doping with Nb2O5, there was no significant impact on the binding energies of Si and Al (Fig. 3e-f, h-i). This indicates that the doping primarily alters the chemical environment of Nb while having minimal effect on the chemical states or electronic environments of Si and Al, which maintain their stability and resistance to interference within the catalyst structure. To further understand the crystal structure of the catalysts, Fig. 4 (a-c) presents the XRD characterization results for Ni/Nb2O5, Ni/HZSM-5, and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalysts. These XRD spectra exhibit several typical diffraction peaks located at 2θ values of 44.5°, 51.9°, 76.4°, and 92.9° These peaks correspond to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of the face-centered cubic (FCC) structure of Ni, identified according to JCPDS card number 04–0850. In the XRD spectrum of Ni/HZSM-5, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni are sharp and well-defined, indicating a high degree of crystallinity in the Ni grains within this catalyst, suggesting good crystal growth and larger grain sizes. In contrast, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni in the Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 sample are shorter and broader. We calculated the grain size of Ni in the XRD patterns of Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalysts by using the Scheller's formula. The average grain size of Ni nanoparticles is 5.4 nm. In general, wider diffraction peaks imply smaller grain sizes, which is consistent with our observation that the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni are shorter and broader. This suggests that the doping of Nb2O5 causes lattice distortion or impedes the crystal growth of Ni, resulting in smaller, more dispersed Ni particles. Smaller Ni nanoparticles mean that the surface area of each particle is larger relative to its volume, thus providing more active sites for chemical reactions. These additional peaks indicate that the structures of Nb2O5 and HZSM-5 are preserved within the composite material. The presence of characteristic peaks for Nb2O5 may be related to its role as a crystal growth inhibitor in the catalyst, while the retention of HZSM-5 peaks emphasizes the contribution of its microporous structure to the catalytic performance. To more clearly reveal the structural details of the catalysts, Fig. 5 presents SEM images at three different magnifications, showing the microstructure and morphological characteristics of the Ni/Nb2O5, Ni/HZSM-5, and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalysts. From Fig. 5 (a, d, g), it is evident that all three catalysts contain large agglomerates of particles with varying sizes and shapes, and some particles have rough surfaces, suggesting the presence of finer secondary structures on their surfaces. At medium magnification, Fig. 5 (b, e, h), the gaps and porous structures between particles become more apparent. These porous structures not only help to increase the surface area of the catalyst but also facilitate the diffusion of reactants and products, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. The high magnification images in Fig. 5 (c, f, i) reveal more detailed fibrous porous structures, with inter-particle stacking forming complex networks. This high surface area structure is highly beneficial for enhancing catalytic performance. Specifically, the Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst combines the mesoporous structure of Nb2O5 and the specific acidity and pore characteristics of the HZSM-5, creating a multifunctional catalytic material. The addition of Ni likely enhances the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst, while the porous structure of HZSM-5 increases its specific surface area. Furthermore, the introduction of Nb2O5 helps disperse Ni particles, preventing their aggregation, which is crucial for maintaining high catalytic activity. To elucidate the microstructural characteristics and properties of different catalysts, Fig. 6 displays TEM images, EDX spectra, and particle size distribution diagrams for Ni/Nb2O5, Ni/HZSM-5, and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalysts. The particle morphologies within these catalysts exhibit varying degrees of irregularity, with some particles appearing smoother while others show rougher surfaces (a-b, e-f, i-j). Notably, significant aggregation among particles suggests that clustering may have occurred during sample preparation or processing. Additionally, the presence of numerous voids between particles, indicative of a porous structure, is beneficial for catalytic performance as it provides increased surface area facilitating the adsorption of reactants and desorption of products. In the TEM analysis, EDX is utilized to identify the Ni composition of the samples and to reveal the uniformity or aggregation of Ni at the nanoscale. Despite observed particle aggregation, the Ni elements inside and around these particles maintain good dispersion (c, g, k). It was observed that the green image of EDX is quite different from the black particles in the TEM. TEM focuses on the overall morphology and structure of the catalyst particles, while EDX focuses on the distribution of the specific element Ni. The green and black areas may not match exactly because the distribution of elements doesn't always align with the physical structure of the particles. Furthermore, since the size and distribution of metal particles directly impact catalyst performance, the particle size distribution histograms are also crucial. Particle histograms were generated from size measurements of particles in TEM images. The diameter of each particle was measured using image analysis software, and these data were grouped into size intervals to create the histogram. Particles that could potentially lead to misclassification due to overlap or edge effects were excluded to enhance the accuracy of the data. The average particle sizes for Ni/Nb2O5, Ni/HZSM-5, and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 are 6.5 nm, 7.2 nm, and 5.5 nm, respectively (d, h, l). The doping of Nb2O5 altered the surface properties of HZSM-5, resulting in a more uniform distribution of Ni on the HZSM-5 and thus increasing the dispersion. Although these changes did not significantly affect the average particle size, they did influence the distribution and activity of Ni nanoparticles. Smaller Ni particles typically have a larger surface area, providing more active sites, which in turn promotes the reaction. Additionally, smaller particles tend to have stronger interactions with the support, enhancing the catalyst's stability and selectivity. The size of the Ni particles also affects the ability to cleave CO bonds. Smaller particles, with more low-coordination sites, are more effective at activating reactants and facilitating CO bond cleavage, thereby improving reaction efficiency. This explanation is also supported by the observed improvement in catalytic performance in our experiments. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the Ni-based catalysts Table 1 shows the actual Ni loading in three different catalysts, while Table 2 presents the experimental results of these catalysts in terms of conversion and product selectivity during the hydrogenolysis of guaiacol. The corresponding gas chromatography (GC) and mass spectrometry (MS) data have been included in the supporting information, and are presented as Figure S1 and Figure S2, respectively. The blank experiment, as well as those using only the HZSM-5 or Nb2O5, failed to achieve effective guaiacol conversion, indicating that these materials do not exhibit catalytic activity in the absence of the active metal Ni. In our work, we compare the performance of Ni-based catalysts based on the mass of Ni, which is a popular approach in literature facilitating comparison of the activity of different catalysts[13,21]. Nonetheless, we recognize that extensive literature compares the activity in terms of the number of surface active sites to describe the nature of active sites more accurately[43,44]. In the Ni/HZSM-5 catalyst, the actual Ni loading is 40.1 %, resulting in a guaiacol conversion of 52.9 % and a phenol selectivity of 90.3 %. The better performance of Ni/HZSM-5 can be attributed to the high Ni loading of HZSM-5, which promotes efficient guaiacol conversion and phenol formation. However, the high loading might also lead to Ni particle aggregation, reducing the utilization of some active sites. In addition, the Ni/HZSM-5 was explored for the variation of reaction time during the hydrogenolysis of guaiacol, as shown in Table S1. The results showed that the conversion of guaiacol did not increase significantly with the increase of reaction time, but showed a decreasing trend. This phenomenon may be due to the deactivation of Ni/HZMS-5. The primary reasons for catalyst deactivation are the oxidation of Ni and the agglomeration of Ni nanoparticles based on XPS and TEM (Figs. 9 and 10). In addition, the selectivity of phenol did not change and remained high despite the increase in reaction time. In contrast, when using Ni/Nb2O5 as the catalyst, the actual Ni loading is 31.4 %, with a guaiacol conversion of 34.1 % and a phenol selectivity of 76.9 %. This suggests that while Ni/Nb2O5 has some catalytic ability, its performance is relatively limited. When Ni and Nb2O5 are co-loaded onto HZSM-5 (Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5), the actual Ni loading is 30.7 %, and the guaiacol conversion significantly increases to 74.4 %, with a phenol selectivity of 85.7 %. Although the calcination temperature and the metal content ratio of Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 were not tightly controlled, we ensured good agreement of the results by repeating the validation through several experiments (Table S2). Additionally, comparative experiments with other Ni-based supported catalysts were conducted. The results demonstrated that the Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 exhibits significant advantages, particularly in its ability to cleave CO bonds and overall catalytic activity (Table 2). The Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 exhibits the highest guaiacol conversion and a high phenol selectivity, likely due to the synergistic effect between Nb2O5 and HZSM-5. According to the previous XRD and TEM characterizations, the addition of Nb2O5 not only improves the dispersion of Ni but also increases the effective surface area of the catalyst, thereby enhancing its catalytic activity. Additionally, FTIR and XPS analyses reveal a strong interaction between Nb2O5 and HZSM-5, leading to the formation of Nb-O-Al and Nb-O-Si bonds. This interaction results in the partial restructuring of the HZSM-5 framework, creating larger pore structures. These structural changes provide better thermal stability for the catalyst, enabling it to operate continuously at high temperatures without structural degradation, further enhancing the overall stability of the catalyst. Generally speaking, temperature and pressure are the primary reaction conditions to be investigated. When the temperature rises, the number of activated molecules increases although the number of molecules remains unchanged, and the rate of the reaction is accelerated accordingly[45]. Therefore, the effect of reaction temperature was first examined and the experimental results are shown in Fig. 7a . The distribution of guaiacol hydrogenolysis products changed significantly in the temperature range of 140–200 °C. The conversion of guaiacol showed an increasing trend with increasing temperature. At 140 °C, the conversion of guaiacol was 42.7 %, and the selectivity of phenol was only 70.3 %. When the reaction temperature was 200 °C, the conversion of guaiacol increased to 89.5 %, and the selectivity of the phenol was as high as 81.7 %. This may be due to the higher temperature increases the thermal movement of molecules and accelerates the chemical reaction rate[46]. These studies used noble metals and homogeneous catalysts, achieving similar reactions at lower temperatures by using water as the solvent[47,48]. In contrast, The Ni-based catalysts face higher energy barriers in CO bond cleavage, requiring more energy to drive the reaction. In the future, we plan to develop hybrid or composite catalytic systems, drawing on the high efficiency of noble metals and homogeneous catalysts, to achieve more efficient and energy-saving reactions. In exploring the conversion of guaiacol to a phenol through hydrogenolysis, the tuning of the reaction pressure appeared to be crucial. As revealed in Fig. 7b, the variation of the reaction pressure caused a significant effect on the conversion of guaiacol and the selectivity of phenol. The conversion of guaiacol showed a tendency to increase with the increase of reaction pressure, and the selectivity of phenol showed a significant decrease. This is because the increase in pressure accelerates the solubility of hydrogen molecules and the hydrogen concentration in the reaction system, which may prompt a series of hydrogenation reactions rather than being limited to the direct conversion of guaiacol to phenol[49,50]. The result is the production of more hydrogenation by-products, such as 2-methoxycyclohexanol, which reduces the selectivity of phenol. The conversion of guaiacol reached 74.4 %, phenol with a selectivity of 85.7 % at 0.1 MPa H2. However, the conversion of guaiacol rose to 96.3 % at 0.6 MPa, the main product was transformed to 2-methoxycyclohexanol, and its selectivity was also significantly enhanced to 49.5 %. Thus, fine-tuning the reaction pressure can not only drive the increase of guaiacol conversion but also, more critically, optimize the high selectivity output of phenol. The choice of solvent has a significant effect on its reaction efficiency and product distribution. This is not only related to the dissociation ability of the solvent but also to its polarity. A comparison of four solvents with different properties, namely water, isopropanol, tetrahydrofuran, and cyclohexane, can reveal the respective solvent effects (Fig. 7c). In particular, the promotion of the reaction was relatively weak when tetrahydrofuran was used as a solvent, as evidenced by the conversion of guaiacol by only 17.6 %, and the formation of relatively diverse by-products including cyclohexanone, cyclohexanol, and 2-methoxycyclohexanol, which showed complex reaction pathways. This complexity could stem from the fact that tetrahydrofuran's polarity is insufficient to stabilize reaction intermediates, leading to the coexistence of multiple reaction pathways. For isopropanol and cyclohexane, both of which are weakly polar solvents but provide relatively stable environments, the conversion of guaiacol was achieved to about 60 % with cyclohexanol as the main product with a selectivity of about 75 %, reflecting a trend towards a more homogeneous reaction. This higher selectivity may be related to the weak polarity of these solvents and their relatively nonpolar environment, which helps maintain more uniform reaction pathways and reduces the formation of by-products. Most notable, however, was the use of water as a reaction medium. Far from just because of its environmentally friendly nature, but also because in water, both the conversion of guaiacol and the selectivity of phenol were optimized, at 74.4 % and 85.7 %, respectively. Water is a highly polar solvent, which can form stable interactions with reactants and products through hydrogen bonding, this interaction promotes the effective adsorption of guaiacol on the active sites, and there are more opportunities for effective contact between guaiacol and the catalysts, which contributes to a higher conversion[51,52]. Notably, these results are consistent with those reported in the literature[22,53]. Catalysts can reduce the activation energy of a reaction to the extent thermodynamically feasible, thereby increasing the rate of the reaction, but at the same time, they are unable to change the equilibrium position of the reaction[54,55]. Theoretically, an increase in catalyst dosage should have a linear positive correlation with the increase in the amount of reaction product produced. However, this is not exactly the case for varying the amount of catalyst used to observe the product yields. Therefore, an investigation of the role of catalyst dosage in correlation with catalytic performance was carried out, and the results of the experiments are shown in Fig. 7d. The conversion of guaiacol showed a tendency to increase and then decrease with the increase of catalyst dosage. The conversion of guaiacol reached a maximum of 74.4 % when the catalyst dosage was 200 mg. When the amount of catalyst was increased to 400 mg, the conversion of guaiacol decreased to 58.6 %. This is because when the catalyst dosage exceeds a certain optimum point, too much catalyst will lead to mutual stacking, reducing the effective contact opportunity of the active sites, and may also introduce side reactions or the catalyst's consumption reactions, thus affecting the overall efficiency of the reaction[56]. In addition, the excessive use of catalyst may also lead to uneven distribution of reactants on the catalyst surface, affecting the homogeneity and efficiency of the catalytic reaction[57]. Additionally, experiments were conducted on the selective HDO of guaiacol over Ni/HZSM-5 and Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalysts to evaluate their reusability, as shown in Fig. 8 . The fresh Ni/HZSM-5 achieved a guaiacol HDO conversion of 52.9 %. However, the conversion dropped to only 13.4 % after the catalyst was used three times (Fig. 8a). In order to confirm whether Ni would further etch under such harsh reaction conditions, the concentration of Ni2+in the reaction solution was determined by ICP-AES. The measured C(Ni2+) is 12.3 mg/L, and the mass loss of Ni is only 0.18 mg (0.09 %), which can be basically ignored. To investigate the reasons for this decline, a series of systematic catalytic characterizations were performed on both the fresh and spent Ni/HZSM-5, as depicted in Figs. 8 and 9 . Initially, the fresh and spent Ni/HZSM-5 catalysts were characterized by XRD as shown in Fig. 9 (a-b). Diffraction peaks corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) crystal planes, characteristic of Ni, were observed in the Ni/HZSM-5 catalyst. Notably, in the spent catalyst, the intensity of these characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni was significantly reduced, whereas the peaks were broader in the fresh catalyst, indicating better dispersion. The average crystallite size of the Ni nanoparticles was 7.3 nm in the fresh Ni/HZSM-5. In contrast, the spent Ni/HZSM-5 exhibited significant agglomeration of Ni nanoparticles, with the average crystallite size increasing to 11.1 nm. This agglomeration of particles is likely the primary reason for the observed decline in activity. XPS analysis was employed to determine the chemical states of Ni in both fresh and spent Ni/HZSM-5 catalysts, with the spectra calibrated using the C1s peak at 284.8 eV. Fig. 9(c-d) displays the spectra fitted for Ni 2p peaks. In both samples, the binding energies of Ni exhibited the same trends. The main peaks at 855.7 eV and 873.8 eV are attributed to the NiO 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks, respectively, due to spin-orbit splitting, representing NiO interacting with the support and highly dispersed NiO on the support. Additionally, the peak at 852.6 eV corresponds to Ni0, and the peaks at 861.9 eV and 879.6 eV are satellite peaks of NiO. Notably, compared to the fresh Ni/HZSM-5, the diffraction peak for Ni0 in the spent Ni/HZSM-5 completely disappeared, indicating that the surface Ni0 was fully oxidized to Ni2+. This complete oxidation of Ni0 to Ni2+ is likely another major reason for the catalyst's deactivation. Characterization analysis via XRD revealed significant agglomeration of Ni nanoparticles in the spent Ni/HZSM-5, which was further confirmed by TEM analysis. TEM images of the fresh Ni/HZSM-5 (Fig. 10a -b) show uniformly dispersed metal particles with small diameters, which contribute to enhanced catalyst efficiency due to the finely dispersed metal particles. In contrast, TEM images of the spent Ni/HZSM-5 (Figs. 10c-d) revealed clear agglomeration of Ni nanoparticles. This agglomeration not only reduces the effective surface area of the catalyst but may also lead to the occlusion of active sites, thus diminishing catalytic efficiency. Notably, after several cycles of use, there was a substantial agglomeration of Ni metal particles, with the largest particles reaching the micron scale. This significant structural change is one of the key factors in the decline of catalyst activity. Ultimately, systematic catalytic characterization methods determined that the main reasons for the deactivation of the used Ni/HZSM-5 catalyst are the complete oxidation of Ni0 to Ni2+ and the agglomeration of Ni nanoparticles. Ni is prone to oxidation, forming NiO that covers active sites, thereby reducing the catalyst's activity and reducibility. Additionally, during cyclic use, Ni particles tend to aggregate, leading to increased particle size, reduced surface area, and decreased dispersion, which ultimately lowers the overall activity. This aggregation typically occurs at high temperatures, driven by the migration and coalescence of Ni particles. To improve the stability of Ni/HZSM-5, we optimized the preparation method (addition of additives) to enhance the dispersion of Ni particles and slow down the aggregation. After doping Nb2O5 into the Ni/HZSM-5 catalyst, its stability was significantly enhanced. After five cycles of use, the Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst achieved an HDO conversion of guaiacol of 68.5 %, with selectivity for phenol of 83.8 % (Fig. 8b). Detailed characterization analysis revealed several beneficial changes induced by the Nb2O5 doping: The pore size of Ni/HZSM-5 was notably increased, which not only enhanced the thermal stability, allowing the catalyst to withstand high-temperature operations without collapsing but also optimized mass transfer. The size of Ni nanoparticles within the catalyst was reduced, improving contact efficiency with reactants and thereby enhancing the conversion. These smaller particles, due to their high surface energy, are more readily stabilized by the support, reducing the migration and agglomeration of Ni nanoparticles and further enhancing catalyst stability. Moreover, the strong interaction between Nb and the HZSM-5 support altered the electronic state of Nb, and this deep-level interaction further solidified the overall structure of the catalyst, enhancing its resistance to high temperatures and mechanical stress. Finally, the spent Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst was also characterized by XRD and XPS (Figure S3). The XRD results showed that the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni remained largely unchanged. According to the Scherrer equation, the average particle size of Ni nanoparticles in the used catalyst was calculated to be 6.2 nm, compared to 5.4 nm in the fresh catalyst, with only a minor difference. This indicates that no obvious agglomeration or deactivation of Ni nanoparticles occurred during the reaction, and the structure and performance of the catalyst were well maintained. Meanwhile, the XPS characterization results further verified this conclusion, showing that a high proportion of Ni0 still existed on the surface of the catalyst, indicating that the catalyst did not undergo a significant oxidization reaction during the process. In summary, these characterization results consistently show that the Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalysts still have excellent stability after usage and are able to maintain their activity and structural integrity over multiple applications. 3.3 The catalytic conversion of real lignin on Ni/Nb2O5-HZSM-5 After studying the catalytic reaction of the model compound guaiacol on Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalysts, it was found that the catalyst not only exhibited excellent activity but also demonstrated remarkable stability. Based on this discovery, the Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 was applied to the catalytic conversion of real lignin (pinewood kraft lignin from Domtar Corporation), aiming to advance theoretical research to practical application. Fortunately, Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 successfully converted lignin, a renewable resource, into a series of alkyl phenolic compounds with significant chemical value through hydrothermal treatment and catalysis under 1 bar H2. The yield of alkyl phenolic compounds reached 17.0 wt% (Fig. 11 ), highlighting the potential industrial application of this method. 4-methylphenol, 4-ethylphenol, and 4-propylphenol can be widely used in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, plastics, and other fine chemical products, offering significant commercial and scientific value[58-60]. BHT is an important phenolic antioxidant widely utilized in rubber, petroleum products, food, essential oils, cosmetics, etc. Similarly, 4-ethylphenol which is obtained from lignin can be converted to 2,6-di‑butyl‑4-ethylphenol in a similar way (Fig. 12 ). It is widely used in high-grade plastics and rubber products and gives good melt index stability and color change resistance at high processing temperatures. In the case of 4-propylmethoxyphenols, it can be catalytically funneled into 20 wt% of phenol and 9 wt% of propylene (based on lignin weight) by gas-phase hydroprocessing and dealkylation. The use of pure water not only served as the reaction medium but also promoted the depolymerization of lignin at high temperatures and atmospheric pressure, providing an environmentally friendly solution to avoiding harmful solvents. Additionally, the introduction of H2 helped maintain reaction stability and reduced unnecessary side reactions, further enhancing the yield of target compounds[61,62]. The success of this study not only proves the feasibility of synthesizing high-value chemicals from lignin but also offers a new perspective for the efficient conversion of biomass resources. This achievement not only promotes the effective utilization of biomass energy but also supports reducing dependence on traditional fossil resources, further laying a solid foundation for the future of green chemistry and sustainable development. To provide a comparison with similar catalytic systems, we have summarized recent progress in the selective conversion of guaiacol to phenol. (Refer to Table S3). Typical reaction conditions include temperatures ranging from 300 to 400 °C and hydrogen pressures from 1 to 65 bar. Precious metal catalysts like Pt/C and Au/TiO2 have achieved high conversion of guaiacol (over 90 %) but relatively low selectivity (30 % to 70 %) at temperatures of 240–300 °C and hydrogen pressures of 1–40 bar [16,63,64]. Mo-based catalysts, used in catalytic hydrogenolysis reactions, require temperatures of 300–450 °C and hydrogen pressures of 20–50 bar to achieve optimal results [65-67]. Fe, Ni, and Re-based catalysts, however, have demonstrated very low conversion rates (<65 %) and selectivity, even under severe reaction conditions[13,68,69]. In this work, we developed a Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst that operates under significantly milder conditions while achieving high performance. The catalyst demonstrated an 89.5 % conversion of guaiacol and 81.7 % phenol selectivity at 200 °C and 0.1 MPa H2. The Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst retains good catalytic activity even after five cycles of reuse. Compared to other Ni-based catalysts, the Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst exhibits a higher yield of phenol (49.1 mmolphenol·gNi −1·h −1), currently achieving the highest phenol yield among Ni-based catalysts. 4 Conclusion In this study, the selective hydrogenolysis of the Caryl-O bond in guaiacol was efficiently performed using Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 under mild conditions, achieving 89.5 % conversion and 81.7 % phenol selectivity. The catalyst demonstrated superior stability and produced the highest phenol yield (49.1 mmol·gNi⁻¹·h⁻¹) among Ni-based catalysts. The incorporation of Nb2O5 improved Ni dispersion, increased the effective surface area, and enhanced the thermal stability of Ni/HZSM-5. Additionally, catalytic depolymerization of lignin in pure water at 240 °C and 1 bar H2 yielded 17.0 wt% of alkyl phenolic compounds. This work introduces a novel approach for biomass conversion in a pure water system, reducing reliance on high-pressure conditions and precious-metal catalysts, and offering new avenues for biomass transformation. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenolysis of CAr-O bonds in lignin to produce aromatic compounds typically necessitates severe conditions. We developed a Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst that facilitates direct cleavage of guaiacol's aryl ether bonds at reduced temperatures (200 °C) and pressure (0.1 MPa H2), achieving a conversion of 89.5 % with the selectivity of phenol at 81.7 %, while retaining its activity after five cycles. The Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 exhibits a higher yield of phenol (49.1 mmolphenol·gNi −1·h −1), currently achieving the highest phenol yield among Ni-based catalysts. The addition of Nb2O5 enhances the dispersion of Ni and augments the effective surface area. In addition, the strong interaction of Nb with the HZSM-5 changed the electronic state of Nb and enhanced the resistance of the catalyst to high temperature and mechanical stress. Employing this catalyst for lignin depolymerization in an aqueous medium led to a 17.0 wt% yield of alkyl phenolic compounds. This approach represents an advancement in biomass resource conversion, circumventing the dependency on high-pressure and precious-metal catalysts, and signaling a new trajectory for sustainable biomass utilization in scientific research.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogenolysis of guaiacol and lignin to phenols over Ni/Nb2O5 HZSM-5 catalyst
